I’ll apologize, but I won’t grovel just because I made a mistake.

meaning: marked by refinement in taste and manners
examples: The mansion had an atmosphere of genteel elegance and decay.
He took elocution lessons to try to make his accent sound more genteel.
a genteel southern lady
The game seemed to be a more genteel version of American football.
When in company, they affected genteel table manners.

meaning: (of a person) speaking with ease by without sinserity
examples: He's a glib, self-centred man.
No one was convinced by his glib answers/explanations.
He’s not flashy, and he doesn’t know how to be glib.

meaning: a slight or superficial understanding of something of a subject; a small amount of something
examples: There's only a smattering of people who oppose the proposal.
I know a smattering of German.
There was a smattering of boos when he was introduced.

meaning: gnaw(bite at or nibble something persistently) into; make resentful or angry
examples: The unkind way in which his girlfriend left him still rankled with him long after.
[ + that ] It still rankles that she got promoted, and I didn't.
[ I ] The way she left him still rankles.

meaning: an abundant supply of something good
examples: The table held a veritable cornucopia of every kind of food or drink you could want.

meaning: reject with contempt
examples: She spurned my offers of help.
Ellis plays the part of the young lover spurned by his mistress.
She spurned his attentions and refused to see him.

meaning: attack in speech or writing
examples: The victim had been assailed with repeated blows to the head and body.
He was assailed with insults and abuse as he left the court.
to be assailed by doubts/fears/problems
Many parents assailed the proposal to lengthen the school day.
After the decision to quit his job, he was assailed by doubts.

meaning: made ineffective or powerless
easily irritated or annoyed
examples: a peevish, bad-tempered person

meaning: taking part in immoral and unethical plots
examples: Officials were accused of conniving with the company in the supply of arms to Sierra Leone.
[ + to infinitive ] They connived to break the school rules at every opportunity.
She had murdered or connived at the murder of one of her lovers.
He called for an independent investigation to find out whether corrupt officials are being bribed to connive in shoddy construction.

meaning: a behavioural attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual
examples: We all have our little foibles.
We all have our little foibles.

meaning: a perceptive understanding
examples: business savvy
She's very intelligent, but hasn't got much savvy.
Teenagers are savvier about handling their digital information than adults.
He dazzled the country as a modern, media-savvy politician.
She has a lot of marketing savvy.
He’s a politically savvy guy.
He showed experience and savvy.
business/media/marketing savvy
savvy investors/businessmen/consumers
commercially/politically/technologically savvy
get/become savvy Repair facilities are going to get savvy and start checking out their customers a little more.

meaning: to leave or merger(a combination of two things) resources, to scrape by
a witty saying or remark
examples: It was Oscar Wilde who made the famous quip about life mimicking art.
[ + speech ] When asked why he seemed to be so relaxed, Mr McCarthy quipped: "It's the drugs".
"Everyone wants to be Cary Grant. Even I want to be Cary Grant," Grant once quipped.
The piano mover quipped, “Of course I love piano – I picked it up as a child!”

meaning: spend thoughtlessly; waste time, money or opportunity
examples: They'll quite happily squander a whole year's savings on two weeks in the sun.
Ireland squandered several chances, including a penalty that cost them the game.
Government should not squander the taxpayers’ money.
Don’t squander your opportunities when you are young.
Fifty-five percent of likely voters are convinced that much of the state's tax money is being squandered.
squander sth on sth Politicians are accused of squandering more than $1 billion on misguided and futile programs aimed at stimulating the economy.
According to one member of the board of directors: "We have squandered the opportunity to become a major player in the industry".

meaning: something that is concise and instructive of a general truth or principle
use of physical or mental energy; hard work; agony and anguish
examples: the recent travails of the airline industry

meaning: wishing or appearing to wish evil to others; arising from intense ill will or hatred
examples: The central character is a malevolent witch out for revenge.
I could feel his malevolent gaze as I walked away.
a malevolent juvenile delinquent

meaning: dull and lacking excitement
examples: We lead such a humdrum life/existence.
Most of the work is fairly humdrum.
We lead such a humdrum life/existence.

meaning: to be in one's duty or obligation
examples: It behooves us to consider our financial situation.

meaning: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences
examples: a foolhardy decision
Sailing the Atlantic in such a tiny boat wasn't so much brave as foolhardy.
It would be foolhardy to try and predict the outcome of the talks at this stage.
He made a foolhardy attempt to climb the tree to recover his kite.

meaning: given to haughty(arrogant superior and disdainful) disregard for others
examples: That's a rather cavalier attitude.
a cavalier attitude toward public health concerns

meaning: collect information bit by bit
examples: From what I was able to glean, the news isn't good.
They're leaving on Tuesday - I managed to glean that much (from them).
From what I was able to glean, the news isn’t good.

meaning: stopping and starting at irregular intervals
examples: intermittent rain
an intermittent noise
Although she made intermittent movie appearances, she was essentially a stage actress.
It rained intermittently all day.

meaning: leniency and compassion shown towards offenders by a person or agency charged with administering justice
examples: The jury passed a verdict of guilty, with an appeal to the judge for clemency.
The governor refused to grant him clemency, and he was executed at 9 a.m. yesterday.

meaning: having an unpleasant smell
examples: The town is built on a malodorous swamp.

meaning: in terrible condition
examples: The hotel we stayed in was really dilapidated.
a dilapidated old car/shed
We still use the dilapidated barn for storing tools.

meaning: involving ignoble actions and motives; arousing moral distaste and contempt; foul and run-down and repulsive
examples: There are lots of really sordid apartments in the city's poorer areas.
He told me he'd had an affair but he spared me the sordid details.
a sordid story
sordid details
The sordid condition of many of the city school buildings was shocking.

meaning: a short instructive saying about a general truth
examples: Oscar Wilde was famous for such aphorisms as "Experience is the name everyone gives to their mistakes".

meaning: compete for something
examples: Six candidates are currently vying for the Democratic presidential nomination.
The two older children tend to vie with the younger one for their mother's attention.
[ + to infinitive ] The two groups of scientists are vying to get funding for their research projects.
Several companies are vying for the contract to build the new hospital.

meaning: uneasiness about the fitness of an action
examples: She had no qualms about lying to the police.
Unfortunately, he said, there are people who have no qualms about bringing in replacement workers for strikers.

meaning: harass, as with question or requests; cause to feel distressed or worried
examples: The town had been besieged for two months but still resisted the aggressors.
When the pop star tried to leave her hotel, she was besieged by waiting journalists and fans.
After showing the controversial documentary, the channel was besieged with phone calls from angry viewers.
fig. After the controversial show, the television network was besieged with complaints.
Mick Jagger was besieged by fans at the airport.

meaning: describing a lively atmosphere
examples: a convivial atmosphere/host
The talks ended on a convivial note.

meaning: refuse to comply
examples: I balked at the prospect of spending four hours on a train with him.
I balked at the prospect of spending four hours on a train with him.

meaning: an incorrect or unsuitable name
examples: It was the scruffiest place I've ever stayed in, so "Grand Hotel" was a complete misnomer.
It's something of a misnomer to refer to these inexperienced boys as soldiers.
Dry cleaning is a misnomer, since the clothes are cleaned in a fluid.

meaning: extreme greed for material wealth
causing annoyance or difficulty
examples: He attempted to tackle the nettlesome issue of police and community relations.
